turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument now in Number 96-670, Murphy Foster v. Scott Love.
Spectators are admonished not to talk until you get out of the courtroom.
The Court remains in session.
General Ieyoub.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court:
This is the Federal Election Day case up from Louisiana.
As Your Honors know, the 42nd Reconstruction Congress put the Federal Election Day statute on the books in 1872.

The question presented is whether the Federal Election Day statute nullifies Louisiana's open primary system under which all registered voters, regardless of party affiliation, vote for their candidates for Senate and United States Representative.

Under Louisiana law as we know it since 1976, if a candidate receives a majority of the votes in the October primary the candidate is declared elected, and there's no contested election on Federal Election Day, shall we say saving the poor working man a trip to the polls in nonpresidential election years.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: General Ieyoub, does any other State, to your knowledge, have this system?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Oklahoma has a similar system, as does Hawaii, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And they each provide, as Louisiana does, for an open primary and no general election if a candidate gets a majority?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Now, California has a system, I believe, of allowing crossover voting in primary elections, is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: I'm not sure, Your Honor.
I believe that's correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And some States allow crossover voting.
In other words, there's a primary election to pick the party's candidate, but parties... people who belong to another political party may cross over and vote--

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --in the party primary.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But in effect Louisiana and you say several other States don't treat the primary election as a party primary.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it does not.
Everyone has a right to vote in the open primary in October, regardless of party affiliation.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mm-hmm.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: And all candidates run in the primary regardless of the party affiliation, so that if there is not a majority vote, then the two top vote-getters go into--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And why is it that Louisiana made that change?
I guess it was not always that way.
It wasn't until the late seventies.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

I do not know why they made that change, Your Honor, but the change was made in 1976, and it actually went into effect in 1978, and since 1978, Your Honor, we have proceeded under the open primary law manner of election.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, you... do you concede that Congress has the power under the Constitution to enact laws affecting the timing of election of Members of the Congress?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

Congress may at any time alter regulations as it see fits, but I would point out that in 20 years, almost 20 years of the open primary, Congress has never moved to try to alter Louisiana's manner of electing its representatives to Congress so as to force a determinative election on Federal Election Day, and Your Honors, the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I guess the question, really, is whether the statutes that Congress did pass are contrary to Louisiana's scheme, as was held in the court below.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, I would argue that it is not.
At the time the statute was passed by Congressman Butler and Senator Thurman in 1872, primaries were unknown.
They did not foresee primaries.

Primaries were a creature of the 20th Century, as fully stated in this Court's decision in United States v. Classic, but they did have the foresight to make exceptions for death or failure to elect, in which case they allowed elections other than on Federal Election Day.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, do you say that Louisiana's system creates a vacancy, so the vacancy statute applies?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Louisiana's system certainly allows for the election of a candidate in October, as opposed to actually electing on Federal Election Day.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, except the Federal statute fixes the Tuesday next after the first Monday in November as the day for election for the Members of Congress.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, and Louisiana's statutory scheme does, in fact, set a date on the first Tuesday after the first Monday.
It does do that.
We simply--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But the election, if there's a majority vote in the primary, does not occur on that date.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Well, that's correct, Your Honor, and I submit that what we have here is an old statute and new circumstances, in which case I think that we have to look to the legislative purpose and the legislative history, as Chief Justice Taney said, looking, if necessary, to the public history of the times in which the statute was passed, and Justice Holmes saying you can look to the respective minds of Congress.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So you accept the proposition that Louisiana law de jure authorizes elections before the Federal election date?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor, a person can be elected de jure under Louisiana's scheme, but what we're saying here is that Thurman and Butler wanted to protect the right to choose, and that is protected by Louisiana's statutory scheme.
What was important, what is important is, as Hamilton said, the right of the people to choose those whom they... who will govern them, and we allow that.
Louisiana's statutory scheme allows that.
That was what was--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But the question is when it's allowed, and I know that it's called an open primary, but would you explain to me why that isn't a misnomer?
As you've said, everyone can vote.
That's the time everyone votes.
It's not like a party primary, and in order to be in the running you must participate.
Now, why aren't those two features, when they're combined... everyone votes.
Everyone who wants to run must be in on this inning.
Why doesn't that add up to an election?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, there is an election on October... in October.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So then that is the Election Day.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: That is the election primary date, Your Honor, and if a person receives a majority of the vote, and only in that instance, they are declared elected, and there would be no determinative election on Federal Election Day.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Yes, but my question to you is, why don't we just call it what it is, that is, an election, since everybody votes, and everybody who wants to be in the running is there?
Why isn't... why is it labeled primary?
It is an election, and it seems to me, being an election it conflicts with the Federal single Election Day.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, it is an election.
It is also a system of voting that winnows down the candidates in many cases, where you have two individuals with the highest vote totals going into a general election on Federal Election Day, but--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you could do that consistent with the Federal day by having, if there are two people, then you have a run-off, as can happen in some States.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Later on, before January.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: That's correct, and that is possible, but the State legislature of Louisiana, which we contend has the primary authority to set the manner of elections, has acted in such a way as to hold this scheme, the open primary scheme, as the law of our State.
If we look at the hist--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But what interest of Louisiana would be affected if Louisiana said, we're going to do our same thing, except we're going to do it on Federal Election Day and, if need be, in the 20 percent of the cases, we'll have a run-off.
Then you would be acting consistently with all of the State goals, and with the Federal law.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Louisiana could do that, Your Honor, but what we're saying here is that Louisiana's open primary scheme in no way really clashes or conflicts with the Federal Election Day statute.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, it does conflict, because it has an election on a day other than the day specified by the Federal statute.
That's why we're here.
Isn't that a clear conflict?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: No, Your Honor, because I believe that you can't necessarily give a literal interpretation in this particular--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: The statute's clear.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --simply because I think that it might... it would lead to unreasonable--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What's unreasonable about it?
Congress has decided that it wants the election to occur uniformly on a given day in November throughout the United States.
What's unreasonable about--

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --We have that, Your Honor.
We have that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --No, you don't have that.
Your election, if there is a majority, occurs in October, not in November.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, we submit that under the sovereignty of the State we have a right at least to set the manner in which our representatives to Congress will be elected, and it does not conflict in the sense that it's closely--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: There is no constitutional authority on the part of Congress to determine the time, uniformly throughout the country?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --There is, Your Honor, but as was pointed out by Mr. Madison in his answer to Mr. Monroe's question about the Times, Places, and Manner Clause, the States should have the primary responsibility.

The reason why the Federal Government might have some control is that they were afraid that if the Federal... I mean, if the State legislatures did not act appropriately, it could bring about the dissolution of the Union, and that's what--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Is it us... is it up to this Court to decide whether Louisiana has acted appropriately in determining whether a pretty clear Federal statute is going to be applied or not?
Is that what you're asking us to do?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
I am... I think that Congress has a right to decide whether or not there is a determinative election on Federal Election Day.
Under Article I, section 5, also--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Do you think that this is a justiciable controversy?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, I do not think it's a justiciable controversy, because I fail to see the injury that the respondents have really suffered.
They had a right to vote.
They had the right to vote in October.
Now--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So that--
--But I want to make sure I understand your position.
Your position, then, is not really an argument about whether the statute applies, and if so, how, and whether there is an inconsistency between it and the Louisiana statute.
Your position is that this issue really does not belong in the court.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, that is my position.
It does not belong in the court.
The right of an individual to vote in any manner is not absolute, and this Court so stated in Burdick v. DeCoushy, that the manner of voting is not necessarily an absolute right.

Now, if Your Honors would look at the appendix, joint appendix on page 43, one of the respondents says, I did not vote in the October open primary in which Billy Tauzin received a majority of the vote and was thereby elected outright under Louisiana law.
I was, therefore, prevented by the Louisiana law from exercising my right under the Constitution and Federal law to vote in an election.

She did not vote in the primary, and now she's saying that since I did not vote in the manner in which Louisiana prescribed, I have been deprived, and I have been injured, and Your Honor, we say that will not do.
That is just not correct, and the matter should not be in this Court.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Then your view is that no voter, as long as they could vote in something they called a primary, would have standing to object to Louisiana's deviating from most of the country in having what is the election a month before everyone else does.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I would say that certainly there would... in our situation, where there is an open primary and an October election, when one fails to vote they have not really suffered an injury to the extent that this Court, or to the extent it would create a justiciable controversy in which this Court--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If you... General Ieyoub, that's how you... if you fail to vote you have no standing, and if you vote you haven't been injured, I suppose, so the result would be that no individual voter could ever challenge the violation, or claim violation of the congressional statute.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Your Honor, when it comes to the manner of voting, I think that's correct, when it comes to a State being able to set forth the manner of voting, as Louisiana has done in the open primary.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but of course, you can have someone who became 21, or whatever your voting age is, on November 1, couldn't have voted in October, but had the Federal statutory right to vote in November but you say, well, that's tough luck.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Your Honor, they do have a statutory right to vote in November.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But there's no election in November under your system.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: At times there are, Your Honor.
At times there are... there is the opportunity to vote in November.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Indeed, most of the time it's resolved in the primary, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: The history has been, Your Honor, that in the past most of the time they have been elected during the primary, and I will point out that under Article I, section 5, the Congress has the authority to challenge the seating of any individual elected to Congress and after 20 years Congress has never moved to remove the credentials of any Louisiana Senator or Congressman because they were elected in October as opposed to November.
I think the results would be unreasonable and impractical to say that if a Congressman got over 50 percent of the vote in a primary, they're not qualified to serve in Congress.

The fact that they would get 50 percent of the vote is an indication of the favor that the people hold him in, and to say that just because it was in October as opposed to an election day in November, that they do not have a right to serve after the people have chosen, I think would lead to unreasonable--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Under that argument you could maybe have your primary in September and then if you need a run-off have that in October.
It would still be all right under your analysis.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You don't... they could... you could just ignore the November date.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Well, we could, but we did not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You didn't.
I understand that.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: We did not, and in fact--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But as a matter of law, if we're trying to figure out what the law requires, you could.
The law really is a nullity as far as it requiring any particular date for the congressional election in Louisiana.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, I submit that the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Maybe it isn't necessary, and maybe it doesn't make any sense, but under your view it seems to me it really just isn't even on the statute books.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Well, I think that Louisiana's scheme really does not in any way offer an abuse to its constitutional authority to set the manner, the primary authority to set the manner of elections.
We have a primary, or an election, in October closely tethered or closely associated with the Federal Election Day in November.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but you don't have to, if the statute means what you says it does.
Maybe you do out of your... you know, the goodness of your heart to try and cooperate with what Congress would like you to do, but you don't have to under your reading of the statute.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Under our reading of the statute, Your Honor, you're correct.

If we have a majority vote-getter in October, then we feel that it's a useless exercise and a useless expense of money and time to have another election and, by the way, that was one of the objectives of passing the Federal Election Day.
Butler and Thurman didn't want multiple Federal elections so that the poor working man would have to take multiple trips to the polls, and that's--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: General Ieyoub, you are making an argument here today, at least in part, that the voters don't have standing and this is not a justiciable controversy.
That was not included in the question, was it, that you brought forward on certiorari?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Your Honor, we have in our brief--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: As I read the question presented, you said the specific question presented is whether the election system employed by the State of Louisiana to elect its Members to Congress conflicts with Federal laws governing the time for holding congressional elections.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And I thought that was the question we were going to decide.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: That... that--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Although you seem to be arguing something different today.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Your Honor, we raised subject matter jurisdiction in our brief.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Not in the question presented, however.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
No, we did not.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Your Honor, we have a very--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Did you raise it in your brief?
I confess not even to have seen it in... I mean, I'm perfectly willing to consider it, even if you didn't raise it.
Gee, I think... I think I ought to consider it, but I didn't even see it in your--

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Your Honor, it's either in the appendix, the joint appendix, or in the brief.
I think it's... it may be in the joint appendix where we raise subject matter jurisdiction, and in any event I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --The joint appendix?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why would it be in the appendix?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --It's certain particular motions that we had filed.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Not in this Court.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: This is all new stuff to me.
I mean, I... you know.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: But Your Honor, I would submit that this Court alone can raise the--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well now, just a minute.
You said you had raised it in your brief.
Where in your brief?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --I apologize, Mr. Chief Justice.
We did not raise it in our brief.

I was thinking of page 24 of the joint appendix, where, in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana we raised that the court lacked subject matter jurisdiction in our answer, in that, so I apologize, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It would have been nice to say something in your brief if you were going to make a big deal about it in your oral argument--

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I made a big deal about it in response to a question by Justice Souter, and I think it's a big deal when you really come down to it.

I think that... in Ex parte Siebold this Court construed Article 1, section 4 not as any Federal juggernaut just totally wiping out regulation, or the manner of regulations that were passed by the State, but what they asked for, what this Court said was that we need cooperation between the Federal sovereignty and the State sovereignty, a harmonizing combination into one system of regulations made by the two sovereignties.
That's what we have here in Louisiana.
The open primary system, it doesn't really clash or conflict.
What it does is, it harmonizes two sovereignties, putting together election regulations.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --But you conceded that you could harmonize also if you just shifted the day that you have this election from October till November.
Then you would be totally on track with the Federal Statute.
You would serve the State purpose.
I don't understand why the harmonizing doesn't work against you, because it seems so easy for Louisiana to comply.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Your Honor, that is within the purview of the State legislature to do exactly what you say.
They chose not to do it in the last legislative session, although they were faced with that issue.

We argue, however, that the history of the adoption of Article I, section 4, title 2, section 7 and its adoption, indicates that at the time it was passed, at the time the... first of all, it indicates that the State has the primary authority to regulate the manner of elections.

Second, it indicates that they didn't foresee primaries, and that primaries have been seen by this Court as an integral part of the electoral process, and that what the statute fathers of... in 1872 were trying to do was to ensure the right to choose, and the people of Louisiana have a right to choose their representatives that go to Congress.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is it not a fact that at least in presidential election years the percentage of voter turnout at the primary is only around 30 percent or so, whereas the percentage of turnout at the November election is in the fifties and sixties percent?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So it does make a... perhaps make a difference to the outcome of the election if you have a very low turnout in one time and a very high turnout in the other.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Well, that's correct, Your Honor, but I submit that Louisiana has had very high voter turnout in the October primary and--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, in 1980 it was 28 percent, I think, in 1984, 31 percent, and at the General Election was over 50 percent.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Well, that's correct, Your Honor, but we still say that we have a very close relationship with the Federal Election Day, not such that it's an abuse of our constitutional authority simply to have a system whereby the person that gets the majority of the vote is elected, and there's no need for another useless election on October, on November 2, or whenever.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: General Ieyoub--

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --what is the State's position, if it has one, on the suggestion of Justice Dennis, or Judge Dennis, who I believe dissented in the court below, that if this is such a problem the Federal court could simply enjoin a declaration that the candidate was elected?
You can't do that any more, but you could still conduct a primary.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
The State's--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That's correct, I know, what Judge Dennis said.
What's the State's reaction to it?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --The State's reaction is that that can be done, and the State's reaction would be that that... we could absolutely do that.
We could have the October primary and just simply not say, well, they're not declared elected, but that they would be declared elected as of the Federal Election Day.
The State would do that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But would they do that with or without putting their names on the ballot in the November election?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: They--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It doesn't seem to me it's much of a change if you simply make your declaration later but don't let anybody vote after the October date.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --We could certainly put the names of the candidates on the ballot, though.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And give them--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --And what happens if the other one wins?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: I'm sorry, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Suppose A gets a majority of the votes in the primary, and then we put their names on the ballot again in November, but more people turn out, and this time B wins.
Who's elected?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Or there's a big scandal in between, and who came in second now comes in first.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Well, Your Honor I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You've got... you're--
--You'd only put one name on the November ballot.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --That's exactly--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Isn't that the answer?
You'd only put one name on.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --That's exactly right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So it would be an election with--

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: That's right, and that's basically what happened in--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Yes or no, I guess.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --That's exactly right, Your Honor.
We would put one name on the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is there a write-in procedure in your State?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --No, Your Honor, there is not.
There's not a write-in procedure.
But my time is--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, what about conforming by putting the two top names, so you have your open primary, as you call it, in October, and then in November, number 1 and number 2 get on the ballot.
You could do that, too.
You just--

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --That--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --You put the second... the one who took second place on even--

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Even if they don't--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --Even if there's a majority?

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Right.
That would be compliance, too, I guess.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that would be compliance.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do you want a Federal court to pick which one of these things will be compliance and enjoin--

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: No.
No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Well then, you don't agree with the dissenting judge below.
Why should we figure out how you should come into compliance?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I'd--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You know, what your State legislature considers severable from the rest of the scheme.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --I suggest that you shouldn't, that it's really Congress.
If Congress wishes to do that, it may do that at any time.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I don't think Judge Dennis' position was that he would leave it to the State to decide.

He... I understood him to say that you could accept all of your opponent's arguments and still solve the constitutional problem by simply declaring unconstitutional that part of the Louisiana statute which declared the person at the October primary who won to be elected, and just say that wasn't so, that there would be only one name on the ballot in November, but the person wouldn't be actually elected until then because you would strike out the declaration.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, that's exactly right.

That's what Justice Dennis said, but prior to the time he said that, he disagreed with the holding of the other two judges that it was in any way a conflict, or that our system was in any way in conflict with the Federal Election Day statute, and we certainly hold to that particular position, that the State has the primary authority from the Court's earliest reading of Article I, section 4, that the State has the primary authority to set the manner of elections.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask if it also means you would take the position that they could say whoever has the most votes in the primary shall be the only candidate whose name appears on the November ballot?
Could you do that?

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Under our present--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, it's not under... but as a matter of... consistent with your legal position as a matter of constitutional Federal law and all the rest of it.
Could Louisiana enact a statute that said the person who has the highest votes in the primary is the only person whose name may appear on the November ballot.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: --I think that it could do that, Your Honor.
And now my time is short, so I'll try to conclude.

We say that the unfounded fears of the Fifth Circuit majority are contrary to this Court's earliest reading of Article I, section 4, and to this Court's harmonizing manner of interpreting Federal statutes and companion State election regulations.
I mean, of course, as in Ex parte Siebold.

Of course regulations made by Congress are paramount and supersede those of the State, but only... and here I quote one of this Court's great judges, Justice Bradley... but only insofar as the two are inconsistent and no farther.
We say there is no conflict, no clash between the Federal Election Day and Louisiana's primary law.
As Justice Bradley said so well in Siebold, let a spirit of national as well as local patriotism prevail.

Let unfounded jealousies cease, and we shall hear no more of the impossibility of harmonious action between the national and State governments on a matter on which they have a mutual and vital interest.
If the Court please Your Honors, the judgment below must be reversed.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, General Ieyoub.
Mr. Baker, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice Rehnquist, and may it please the Court:
The key issue in this case, Your Honors, is that this is not an attack on Louisiana's prerogative to maintain this type of election system.
Justice Ginsburg got it exactly right.

Louisiana can maintain what it has, but it has to conform it to the requirements of Federal law, and that would mean this primary, which is really an election, on Federal Election Day, with a run-off thereafter as required by section 8.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: There's about 20 percent of the cases where a runoff is held now.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: That's correct, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So under your proposal on... and I take it those are the closest elections, so under your proposal the closest elections are the one where there's the lowest turnout.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: I'm not sure I understand the question, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, if the close elections are this, this 20-percent category, under the corrective remedy that you've just proposed the closest elections are going to be decided by the ones with the lowest turnout.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is that the only corrective, or could... would it suffice in your view if Louisiana simply certified the successful candidate on the Federal Election date?
He had to be alive, and then he's to get certified?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: Well, it... Justice Kennedy, with respect to the former, the hypothetical you gave me, the Federal statute requires that any runoff election be held at some point after the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I understand that.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --And the fact that turnout may be lower is inconsequential to the Federal statutory scheme.

That's just a fact of life, and that... we saw that in Georgia in 1992, where Georgia had an election for the United States Senate in which no candidate obtained a majority of the vote in November and there was a run-off thereafter, at which point the turnout was actually lower.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Mr. Baker--
--What about the next point?
Can... would it be satisfactory if this election scheme basically stayed in place but the winner was just certified as of the General Election date?
He had to be alive, his name on the ballot?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: Not at all, Justice Kennedy, and... not at all, because the real election, the de jure election, is in fact still on--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, suppose it's not de jure any more.
He's certified under... Louisiana changes the law simply to certify the winner on the Federal Election Date.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --If there's no opportunity to cast... if there's no possibility for a choice on Federal Election Day, Louisiana has foreclosed an election on Federal Election Day, and it's legally impossible--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is that with every single election?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Well, if--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: With every single candidate?
In every one of the States there has to be an opponent on the final election date, on the Federal election date?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --State law has to provide for the possibility of an election.
That is, there has to be the possibility of an election on Federal Election Day.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, there is on Louisiana.
If the... if one person doesn't get a majority, there will an election on Election Day.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: 20 percent of the time.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So you have no problem.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: I have... well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You can go home.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Your Honor, the statute doesn't say you can have an election for Federal office only 20 percent of the time.
It says in every Federal election the election must occur on--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So you demand more than a possibility of an election on Election Day.
What do you demand?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --An election, Justice--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: An election on Election Day.
Then what do you do about the States that have a filing requirement and only one person files?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --The State has provided for the possibility--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Ah, you're back to possibility, now.
Which is it?
Is a possibility enough, or does it have to be a certainty?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --A possibility is sufficient as long as State law hasn't foreclosed--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do you have a possibility here?
How do you distinguish the... I mean, I wonder, you know, where this case leads us to.
What do you do with those... what do you do with the State where only one... both parties nominate the same person?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Where both parties have nominated the same--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You have party primaries, closed party primaries--

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --And both of them nominate the same person, Dwight David Eisenhower, or whoever, you know, some great American--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Or Earl Warren in California.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Or Earl Warren in California, and comes Election Day there's no election on Election Day.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: If... well, there's an election to the extent that State law provided for the possibility of more than one person being on the ballot.
An election was provided for.
Through the State's ballot access rules, only one person appeared to qualify for--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Through Louisiana's primary rules only one person qualified.
I mean, it's the same thing.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --That's not correct, Justice Scalia.
Through Louisiana's... Louisiana's primary is not a qualifying primary.
It elects Members of Congress in October.
Only to the extent that there is a failure to elect in the Louisiana primary is, in fact, there an election in October.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So you--
--But in answer to my question you said that if the certification laws were changed, and you just... and Louisiana just delayed certification until the General Election, that would not be sufficient.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: That's... it's not a question of timing or certification, Justice Kennedy.
It's a question of the timing of the election that selects the Member for office.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It's a question of what is a de jure election, I suppose, and--

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: On--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --it's very clear that there is a possibility that the de jure election will be in... on the Federal election date, and you've indicated that's all that's necessary, and that's what Louisiana has.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --No, Justice Kennedy.
Justice Kennedy, Louisiana has a conclusive election in its October primary.
The voters--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, only if some candidate gets a majority.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --But--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I mean, you're all tangled up in your possibility language.
It doesn't wash.
[Laughter]
It doesn't fly.
You're... I don't know what you're up here arguing.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Because the--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: There are statutes, as my colleagues have indicated, where you could end up with a two-party primary, and the same candidate on the ballot in November, so that it's only one name, or you could have a situation where one party doesn't make a nomination, and again there's only one name.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Your--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is that a problem?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --No, it's--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And Louisiana presumably could go to a system whereby they still have their primary election but they provide that the... if there is a majority winner at the primary election date, that name has to go on the General Election ballot before it's official that there's an election.
Now, will that do it?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --No, Justice O'Connor.
In response to your hypotheticals, those are all situations in which the party primaries are not conclusive as a matter of law.
The party primaries have merely nominated a person who may appear on the November ballot.
The Louisiana October primary is conclusive as a matter of law.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well then, all then... if that's your argument, then all Louisiana would have to do to meet your contention is to say the October primary isn't conclusive.
The person still has to be alive in November and be on the ballot, and it's that time that he's officially elected.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: If it's not possible, if it's not legally possible for the winner of the primary in October to lose in November, if it's not... if a State doesn't allow for some other candidate to appear on that ballot, if by winning that October primary you have won the election, that... you're selected for office, that's the violation of the Federal statute.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but then you're... then you have trouble dealing with the question whether... where both parties nominate the same candidate, and there is only one candidate on the November ballot.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: But that satisfies Federal law because those primaries, Chief Justice Rehnquist, were not conclusive.
They did not select, as a matter of law, the person for Congress.

A primary, as traditionally understood, merely selects a person to appear on a ballot, either a partisan nominee, or otherwise serves the function of... it's a ballot access funnel, and it winnows down the number of candidates who will ultimately appear on a General Election ballot, but it doesn't select Members of Congress.
An election does, and that's the crucial--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Then you're back to the Chief Justice's earlier question.
All you have to change in this law is the determination that he's elected, and just say, you know, he'll... this is just a primary, and he'll be the only candidate on the ballot in November.
I don't see how you can get around that, unless you want to repudiate those State laws that allow partisan primaries, both of which can name the same candidate.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Justice Scalia, we don't--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That candidate's the only name on the ballot, and the same would be the case in Louisiana.
Whoever gets a majority in the primary, his will be the only name on the ballot.
What's the difference?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --The difference is, Justice Scalia, is that the hypotheticals you gave me, the two... there are two partisan primaries.
The part... that each provide a place on the ballot.
Neither primary is conclusive as a matter of law.
This Louisiana October primary is conclusive, and merely delaying the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I understand that.
But I'm asking the Chief Justice's question.

If all that you changed about Louisiana law was the statement that the primary is conclusive if someone wins a majority, if you just change that and say he's not elected then, he will be the only name on the ballot in November, would that make you happy?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --No, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Then you've got to tell me why that's any different from the two-party primary that puts one name on the ballot in November.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: It's not... Justice Scalia, that's not an election, because there's not the possibility... State law has not allowed for... assuming there's no write-in possibility, what section 7 requires is an election on Federal Election Day, which--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But you're saying one thing more.
You're saying there's got to be a... how shall I put it +/?
a legally unconditional opportunity for voting on the November date.
That's what you're saying, isn't it?
Not merely a possibility.
You're saying that the possibility has got to be legally unconditional.

Now, if the voters make a choice, as in the Earl Warren case, that would not be a problem under your criteria, because the law was not precluding the possibility of the voting that you're talking about.
You're saying that the law cannot preclude that opportunity, and this law does in the 80 percent of the cases.
Isn't that what you're arguing?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Absolutely, Justice Souter.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right, and do we have to get into this other issue?
I mean, I don't know, maybe in California my recollection is they all provided for writeins.
I don't know whether they do or don't.
Maybe all these other... I don't know what Louisiana will do.
I mean, here the statute says now a candidate who receives a majority of the vote that's cast for office in a primary election is elected.
Now, do we have to go into the question of what happens if that is illegal under the statute and they decide to fix it up by declaring him elected or not?
Is it necessary or not necessary for us to go into that?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: It's not necessary, Justice Breyer.
A declaratory... affirming the court of appeals, and the declaratory judgment of the court of appeals as satisfactory, then it will be the prerogative of the--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: In other words, the court of appeals just dealt with this language, so if they decide to fix it up through this... saying, okay, they changed the words, so a candidate who receives the majority of the votes cast for office in a primary election will have his name placed on the ballot in November and no one else will, and there are no write-ins.
If that's how they fix it up, then we have to deal with this question we're now discussing?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Absolutely, Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll also have to deal with the writing of an opinion in this case.
Yes.
I mean, we can't simply say in one word, the judgment of the court of appeals is affirmed.
We customarily give reasons why we're affirming.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Sometimes.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: I wouldn't object to that, Chief Justice Rehnquist.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what reasons would you suggest we give for affirming?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: The reasons that I would provide is that the State statute is in hopeless conflict with Federal law.
Federal law requires a uniform national date for congressional elections, Louisiana law provides for conclusive congressional elections in October that cannot be reconciled--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Mr. Baker, did I understand you to agree with me... I think General Ieyoub did... that when you have the two things, one is everybody votes in this, call it what you will, in this thing, and to be in the running you must run in this thing, that whatever label you put on it, that is an election, unlike a primary, where only Democrats can vote in one, Republicans can vote in the... they're not specific.
This is everybody who wants to vote votes in this.
Everybody who wants to run runs in this.
What is that, and if the answer is, an election, then you have a conflict with the Federal statute.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Absolutely, Justice Ginsburg, which leads me to respond to a point made by my colleague, the Attorney General.
The Attorney General suggested that partisan primaries were unknown in 1872, and he's absolutely right, so this is not a situation of applying old law to new facts.
We're applying old law to, in fact, an election system that Congress exactly understood at the time it enacted this statute.
Congress... in 1872 there were elections.
There were no pre-election primaries.
But Congress also anticipated that States in these elections might have majority vote requirements.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But let me just... are you--

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --If you are, let me go back to the Chief Justice's question, because I was asking seriously whether we have to reach it, and to force you to focus on it, I'll say, now we are writing the opinion in your favor, hypothetically, and we come to the section where... remember the alternative I gave you you said we didn't have to reach, they change it, all right, to say only this name appears on the ballot and no write-ins?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.

It is argued that it would be fine to have a statute that says, no write-ins, and the only name on the ballot, and that this statute is the same, but that argument is unconvincing, because... and now I want you to fill in the blank.
[Laughter]
That's why I'm uncertain whether we have to reach it.
How would you fill in the blank?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: The argument is unconvincing because the election that selected the Member for office was held in October, and there was no election in November, Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Baker, maybe I misunderstood you, but I think the premise of Justice Breyer's question is that it would be okay to comply just by saying that the one who gets the most votes in October is on the ballot, and nobody else, and nobody else qualifies.
I thought your answer to that was that that would not be compliance with the Federal elections statute.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: That's... maybe I misunderstood Justice Breyer's question.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So--

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: That would not comply with the Federal--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --But it would if you said the two top runners.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --That's... there are numerous correct, Justice Ginsburg... there are numerous possibilities for fixing this system so that it--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I see two.
One is, you move the... what they call the open primary to Election Day.
Another one is, you put the top two.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Or maybe the first and the last.
[Laughter]
I mean, that would give you an election on Election Day, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What if you had a scheme in which the Louisiana statute said, whoever gets a majority in October will be on the November ballot and will be the only name on the November ballot, and there will be no write-ins, but unless in November that person gets at least one vote, that person will not or cannot be elected, would that satisfy the Federal law?

The reason I ask the question is, I think what you're saying is, there's got to be voting on the November date which is operative to elect, and in my silly hypothetical there would in fact be voting in November that would be operative to elect, and so that's why I'm asking.
Is that sort of the nub of what you're arguing here?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --It would be... well, under your hypothetical it would be legally possible to be elected or not be elected if a candidate did receive a vote, as I understand your hypothetical.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That's right.
Nobody votes for the October winner, and therefore no one is elected for that office.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: Which is distinguished from most... all right, under that... if State law were as you posited it, Justice Souter, and it would only take one vote to elect this person, this person was on the ballot, there would be an election on Federal Election Day, but it would not... there would be serious, profound questions raised whether or not this election satisfied this Court's First and Fourteenth Amendment jurisprudence--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What is the reason for that?
Are you saying the reason is there's got to be a choice as between at least two candidates on that date?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --An election, by definition, presupposes a choice.
That's--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Or at least an opportunity so far as State law is concerned for a choice.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Correct, Justice Souter.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Now, wait a minute, there is a choice.
You... I mean, you don't say there has to be a choice, because you say it's okay if you have two separate primaries and you have no choice on Election Day.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: But what has happened... two separate primaries that have elected the same nominee--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes.
There's no choice.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --The State law has not prevented that choice, Justice Scalia.
It's the choice of the voters in a preceding... State law has allowed for the possibility of an election in November.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why should it make any difference that in one hypothesis the reason you have only one name is on the ballot is there were two separate primaries and in both of those the same person, and in the Louisiana case there were a number of people on the ballot and only one person survived.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: The difference, Justice... Chief Justice Rehnquist is that the... that those primaries, neither primary elected as a matter of right the person to office.
Each primary merely selected a person who happened to be the same person to appear on that ballot.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And why does that make a difference?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: Because the State law has provided for its conclusive election in November.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask a question... we're talking about a lot of hypotheticals here.

Since the decision of the court of appeals in this case, do you know whether or not the Louisiana legislature has given any attention to what remedy it might provide for this, or are they just sitting waiting for us?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: Yes, Justice Stevens, they looked at this in the most recent legislative session.
There were some efforts to address the problem, and then they decided apparently to wait until this Court's disposition of this case, so the legislation went nowhere.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Do you know... have you looked up, or do you know how many States other than Louisiana do not allow write-ins on the November election?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: I don't know the answer to that, Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Do we know if there are any others?
Is it common?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: I know that Hawaii doesn't allow--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Does not?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Does not allow write-in--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So there are other States.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --That's--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: There are other States that don't allow write-ins in the primaries?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Correct, Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well then, we may have to reach the--

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: Section 8--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Would you be happy if there were a write-in provision?
I mean, if there were just a write-in?

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Absolutely, Justice Scalia.
That would satisfy... there would be an election.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: There would be a real election.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: There'd be an election.
Now, whether or not that election--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So I guess you'd be satisfied if we allowed the... you know, the first and the last in the primary to be put on the ballot.
Right?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Anything.
Just pick a name.
You know--

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --There... well, not anything, Justice Scalia.
There has to be the... as long as there is the possibility for a choice in November--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Right--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --That's the problem.
I can understand why you'd want to limit it, because if you can limit it any way at all, even with one vote, or even with the first and last, you've distinguished your case.
I understand that.
Now we don't have to reach the others.

But what's worrying me now is that if we say here there is no election, it's not an election, then there may be X other States that suddenly will discover they don't have an election in November for the reason that it is more than theoretically possible that both parties have selected the same nominee, and that's what is driving this concern, and at the moment I don't know the answer to that.
It seems to me a genuine concern, and that's... I mean, everybody's asking you to focus on it.
I don't want to give up before getting the most out of your thought on this that I can.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Well, Justice Breyer, if a State's ballot access selection device is not conclusive as a matter of law, that ballot access selection device in the form of a primary would pass muster under the Federal statutes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: In other words, you're saying that if Hawaii or other States that don't have write-ins in November do end up with the Democratic and Republican parties selecting the same candidate, that their election will be invalid.
That's your position.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: That's not my position, Justice--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
Well, I... then... it sounds as if it is.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --Well, Justice Breyer, that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It ought to be, if I understand the rest of your argument, or if it isn't, then the rest of your argument has to be different.
I... You keep--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --I think if people had focused on this we'd have a few briefs here from other States that would be concerned about it, and so I'm a little uncertain what to do.
It seems to me it's coming up for the first time now.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Baker, I thought that you had answered my question that this is an election when everybody votes.

I thought that was your distinction between party primaries that happen to come up with the same candidate but not everybody votes together, and this, which you agreed, I thought, that it is an election because everybody votes and everybody who's running must run, that those two things in combination equal an election, and if that's so, then you would distinguish your case from the party primaries that may happen to come up with the same candidate.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: --That's correct, Justice Ginsburg, and for the added reason that those party primaries don't as a matter of law select the congressional officer.

They simply have selected a nominee who will appear on a ballot, and if by happenstance the same person has been chosen by the respective Democratic and Republican primaries, the election is still held in... the conclusive election is held in November, and the primaries were not legally... were not the legal selection of the congressional officer.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And Louisiana has been candid in describing its system, because it says, if you have somebody who comes out of this race, whatever it is, with a majority vote, that person is elected.

turn.speaker: m_miller_baker
turn.label: Mr. M. Miller Baker
turn.text: Correct.
That's correct, Justice Ginsburg, and section 8, the companion statute to section 7, 2 U.S.C. section 8, is a statute that answers this... that gives us the answer in this case.
Elections in 1872 were like the elections that Louisiana has today.
Everybody appeared at the polls.
Everybody voted.

In most States, a plurality election was sufficient to elect a person to Congress, but a number of States have majority vote requirements as does Louisiana today, so therefore Congress inserted section 8 into title 2 to provide for the contingency of a failure to elect on Federal Election Day, and that's the statute that Louisiana could follow and have its post Federal Election Day run-off if it so chose to do that.
If there are no further questions, that concludes my argument.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Baker.
General Ieyoub, you have 2 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: richard_i_ieyoub
turn.label: Mr. Richard I. Ieyoub
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, I have no rebuttal.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you.
The case is submitted.
